Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the era of Newton, mathematics has been a key tool in helping us comprehend the nature of the universe. Famous examples are calculus via Newtonian mechanics and differential geometry via Einstein's theory of general relativity. During the last twenty years, there has been a great deal of activity devoted to building a so-called string-theoretic model of the universe, which incorporates some of the most sophisticated mathematics. The subject of Gromov-Witten theory was born twenty years ago during a period of intensive interaction between mathematics and physics. Since then Gromov-Witten theory has established itself as a central area in both geometry and physics. At the same time, it has expanded greatly in its scope to many diverse areas of mathematics, ranging from the classical topic of Hurwitz theory to the modern area of Donaldson-Thomas invariants (the sheaf-theoretic counterpart of Gromov-Witten theory). Despite its success, many central problems remain unsolved. Two notable examples are the computation of higer genus Gromov-Witten invariants of compact Calabi-Yau manifolds and the precise relation between Gromov-Witten and Donaldson-Thomas invariants. The resolution of these problems is of great importance for geometry and physics. In this proposal, a team of the best experts in the world is assembled to attack these central problems. In addition, the PIs propose to develop technology to study a variety of questions relating Gromov-Witten theory to enumerative algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry and mathematical physics. The PIs hope to make important and substantial contributions to these areas of mathematics, and their interrelations.

This project is interdisciplinary in nature, in that both physical and mathematical ideas play central roles. In this sense it adds to the current trend of interaction between mathematics and physics. This project emphasizes teamwork and collaboration. Through research seminars, organizing and participating in national and international conferences, this proposal will also enhance the training of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral fellows. There will be a number of research publications that will help in introducing students to this exciting area of mathematics.

This award is cofunded by the Algebra and Number theory and the Topology programs of DMS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to collaborate on the research subjects GW invariants, DT invariants, and research topics inspired by their developments.

GW invariants and DT invariants are invariants of Calabi-Yau threefolds, and more generally of symplectic manifolds, inspired by Super-Strings theories in mathematical physics. The study of these invariants has had profound impact to the research in mathematics in general, and will continue to do so. This project was set to promote the collaboration among research groups in three US universities: Columbia University, Stanford University, and University of Michigan.

At Stanford University, this project has been led by three Principal Investigators (coPI) Ionel, Li and Vakil. Ionel was focusing on proving the Gopakumar­Vafa conjecture, under the support of this grant, of six dimensional symplectic manifolds. This conjecture is about the structure of GW invariants of Calabi-Yau threefolds (six dimensional symplectic manifolds).

Li was working on developing an effective theory of all genus GW invariant of quintic Calabi­Yau threefolds. He is aiming at developing such a theory that eventually will determine such invariants explicitly. This project was inspired by the vision of mathematical physicist Witten.

The goal of Vakil was to determine the Chow ring (with Q-coefficients) of the moduli space of curves, using techniques inspired by the DT theory. Another goal was to find stabilization results analogous to those in topology for moduli spaces, and develop categorically correct and solid foundations for tropical geometry.

The postdoctor supported by this project, Shen, was working on Landau­-Ginzburg/Calabi­Yau correspondence for elliptic orbifold projective curves via modularity.

The PI of this project has been working diligently, and collaboratively, on these goals. During the span of this project, they have achieved significant progress, proved several outstanding results, and satisfactorily reached the initial goal of this project.

The coPI Ionel used geometric and analytical, jointly with T. Parker, proved the Gopakumar-Vafa conjecture for all symplectic 6­dimensional manifolds. They also extended this result to genus zero GW invariants of semipositive symplectic manifolds.

The PI Li, along with coPI C.C. Liu from Columbia, and two other collaborators H.L. Chang and W.P. Li, developed a Mixed-Spin-P field theory valued in the master space that realizes the two GIT quotients related to the quantic Calabi-Yau threefolds. Using this theory, they have discovered infinitely many polynomial relations among all genus GW invariants of quintic threefolds and of FJRW invariants of Fermat quintic polynomial. Before they, jointly with H.L. Chang and W.P. Li, they completed a work on top Chern class of Witten, necessary for their work on Mixed-Spin-P fields theory.

The coPI Vakil, along with M. Wood, developed a general theory of discriminants in the Grothendieck ring, which has had impact in other fields (notably topology and number theory). Related ideas led an understanding of the full Chow ring of the moduli space of genus 6 curves, by the coPI and Penev.

The postdoc Shen proved the Landau­Ginzburg mirror symmetry conjecture of all genus between FJRW theory of an invertible quasi­-homogeneous polynomial and Saito­Givental theory of the mirror polynomial. He built a moduli for Saito­Givental theory of invertible quasi-homogenous polynomials. This gave a comparison between all genus GW invariants of maximal quotient of any Fermat Calabi-Yau hypersurface and all genus FJRW invariants of Fermat Calabi­Yau singularity.

The project provided much opportunities on communications and interactions among members of the algebraic geometry group in Stanford University. Through workshops, and other means of communications supported by this grant, it also helped collaborative works of research groups in three campus Columbia, Michigan and Stanford.

This project allows coPI’s to train graduate students. Students of coPI’s are working under the support of this project. The project supported one postdoctor.

Work coming out of this grant has led to a lecture series at the Arizona Winter School in Number Theory by coPI Vakil. The working groups led by him at the Arizona Winter School involved a large number graduate students, contributing to the "training" objectives of this grant.  

The coPI’s have organized the workshop "Moduli spaces of curves and maps" from Feb. 12 to 15 at Stanford University, supported by this grant.

The result proved by coPI Ionel is a fundamental theorem in GW invariant subject. The Mixed­Spin­P field theory developed by PI Li will provides a new theory to study, and to help explicitly determine all genus GW invariants of quintic Calabi­Yau threefolds. The general theory of discriminants in the Grothendieck ring developed by coPI Vakil has already had an impact in many fields (notably topology and number theory).

The results proved by PI’s will significantly advance the investigation of GW invariants, FJRW invariants, and LG models. The results proved will impact on mathematical physics, especially superstring theory.

This project has provided topics and problems for one junior researcher and several graduate students at Stanford University.
